instruction: Prove the closed form of the recurrence.
claim: Suppose that f: ℤ⁺ → ℤ is defined by f(1) = 5, f(2) = -5, and f(n) = 4f(n-2) - 3f(n-1) for all n ≥ 3. Use (strong) induction to prove that f(n) = 2 × (-4)^{n-1} + 3.

Use (strong) induction to prove that the following claim holds: For any integer n ≥ 2, if p_1, …, p_n is a sequence of integers and p_1 < p_n, then there is an index j (1 ≤ j < n) such that p_j < p_{j+1}.
solution: Induction on n. Base case n=2: The sequence is p_1, p_2 with p_1 < p_2. So j=1 satisfies p_j < p_{j+1}. IH: Assume the claim is true for sequences of length 2 up to k. Step (length k+1 sequence: p_1, …, p_{k+1} where p_1 < p_{k+1}): Choose an intermediate element p_m where 1 < m < k+1. If p_m > p_{k+1}, then p_1 < p_{k+1} < p_m, meaning p_1 < p_m. By IH on the first m elements, there exists an index satisfying the property. If p_m ≤ p_{k+1}, then we can apply IH on the suffix subset p_m … p_{k+1} to find our index. In either case, the local drop exists. □
